docs.snippet: HOUSTON, Oct. 29 (AP) - Lehman Brothers has agreed to pay $222.5 million to settle a class-action lawsuit contending that it and other brokerage firms and banks helped Enron mislead investors....
docs.lead_paragraph: Lehman Brothers has agreed to pay $222.5 million to settle a class-action lawsuit contending that it and other brokerage firms and banks helped Enron mislead investors. The University of California, the lead plaintiff in a conglomerate of lawsuits filed in Houston, announced the settlement Friday. The university lost nearly $150 million when Enron went bankrupt.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Who Audits the Auditors?,'' by Arthur Levitt (Op-Ed, Jan. 17):     Having witnessed firsthand the devastating effects of Arthur Andersen's blindness to Enron's economic chicanery, is there anyone who can now defend the Bush ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Who Audits the Auditors?,'' by Arthur Levitt (Op-Ed, Jan. 17): Having witnessed firsthand the devastating effects of Arthur Andersen's blindness to Enron's economic chicanery, is there anyone who can now defend the Bush administration's risky proposal to invest Social Security money in the stock market?
docs.abstract: Letter from Adam Cohen wonders who would defend Bush administration's risky proposal to invest Social Security money in stock market after witnessing devastating effects of Arthur Andersen's blindness to Enron's economic chicanery

docs.lead_paragraph: POWER FAILURE The Inside Story of the Collapse of Enron. By Mimi Swartz with Sherron Watkins. Illustrated. 386 pp. New York: Doubleday. $26. FINAL ACCOUNTING Ambition, Greed, and the Fall of Arthur Andersen. By Barbara Ley Toffler with Jennifer Reingold. 273 pp. New York: Broadway Books. $24.95. INFECTIOUS GREED How Deceit and Risk Corrupted the Financial Markets. By Frank Partnoy. 464 pp. New York: Times Books/Henry Holt & Company. $27.50.
docs.abstract: Floyd Norris reviews following books: Power Failure: The Inside Story of the Collapse of Enron by Mimi Swartz with Sherron Watkins; Final Accounting: Ambition, Greed, and the Fall of Arthur Andersen by Barbara Ley Toffler with Jennifer Reingold; and Infectious Greed: How Deceit and Risk Corrupted the Financial Markets by Frank Partnoy (M)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: POWER FAILURE: THE INSIDE STORY OF THE COLLAPSE OF ENRON (BOOK)

docs.snippet: Securities regulators accused H&R Block on Monday of defrauding investors by selling them $16 million worth of bonds in Enron in the five weeks before it collapsed....
docs.lead_paragraph: Securities regulators accused H&R Block Inc. yesterday of defrauding individual investors by selling them $16 million worth of bonds in the Enron Corporation in the five weeks before it collapsed amid a major accounting scandal. About 200 brokers at H&R Block's investments unit, H&R Block Financial Advisors Inc., sold the bonds to 820 customers in 40 states without telling them how risky the bonds were, according to a statement by NASD, the private-sector regulator that oversees the securities industry.
docs.abstract: National Assn of Securities Dealers charges that about 200 brokers at H&R Block Financial Advisors Inc defrauded investors by selling them $16 million in Enron Corp bonds five weeks before Enron collapse without disclosing high-risk nature of investment; will seek disgorgement of profits and restitution for customers; Block earned about $500,000 on sales; photo (M)

headline.main: H&R Block Is Accused Of Fraud In Bond Sales

docs.snippet: HOUSTON, Sept. 23 - In the most damaging testimony so far in the first Enron trial, a former credit analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company testified Thursday that in 1999, she heard several executives of her firm discuss a side deal that the governmen...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the most damaging testimony so far in the first Enron trial, a former credit analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company testified Thursday that in 1999, she heard several executives of her firm discuss a side deal that the government says was at the heart of a criminal conspiracy to bolster the energy company's earnings illegally. In her testimony, the analyst, Tina Trinkle, said that she had participated in a conference call with several of the defendants, and heard that Enron had said it would buy back an investment it wanted to sell to Merrill within six months if no other buyer could be found.
docs.abstract: Tina Trinkle, former credit analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co, testifies at Enron trial that in 1999 she heard several executives of her firm discuss side deal that government says is at heart of criminal conspiracy to bolster energy company's earnings illegally; says she participated in conference call with several of defendants, and heard that Enron had said it wanted to sell to Merrill within six months if no other buyers could be found; testifies Daniel Bayly, Merrill's former head of global investment banking, pressed to get Enron's commitment in writing, but was told by subordinate that it could not be done without jeopardizing accounting on deal (M)

headline.main: Witness Tells of Hearing Talk About Merrill-Enron Side Deal

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) - The Enron Corporation made more than $1.67 billion in Western states over a six-year period that included the region's energy crisis - money the company, now in bankruptcy protection, may be required to return, federal e...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation made more than $1.67 billion in Western states over a six-year period that included the region's energy crisis -- money the company, now in bankruptcy protection, may be required to return, federal energy officials testified Monday. Officials in California immediately criticized the estimate as more than $1 billion too low.
docs.abstract: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission says Enron Corp made more than $1.67 billion in Western states over six-year period that included region's energy crisis--money the company, now in bankruptcy protection, may be required to return; California officials immediately criticize estimate as more than $1 billion too low; Enron is accused by California officials of gaming state's power market and scheming to cheat customers (M)

headline.main: Witness Details Enron's Income in Energy Crisis

docs.snippet: The British oil and gas producer BG said that a deal to buy Enron Oil and Gas India had expired. BG said progress to conclude the deal had been slower than anticipated after Enron filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the United States. BG...
docs.lead_paragraph: The British oil and gas producer BG said that a deal to buy Enron Oil and Gas India had expired. BG said progress to conclude the deal had been slower than anticipated after Enron filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the United States. BG had originally agreed to buy the Enron Indian unit for $338 million and had hoped to conclude the deal by the end of this year. The acquisition would have given BG access to oil fields and gas fields on India's west coast.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: India: Enron Purchase Collapses

docs.snippet: Elements of Andrew S. Fastow's testimony appear at odds with other information that has developed in the case....
docs.lead_paragraph: No two witnesses in a criminal trial ever tell exactly the same story. Prosecutors and defense lawyers expect it. That seems to be holding true in the testimony of Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron. Elements of Mr. Fastow's testimony at the criminal trial of his former bosses appear at odds with other information that has developed in the case, including the sworn statements given in another trial by his former lieutenant, Michael J. Kopper.
docs.abstract: Elements of testimony given by former chief financial officer Andrew Fastow at criminal trial of former bosses at Enron appear at odds with other information that has developed in case, including sworn statements given in another trial by Michael Kopper; Kopper was government witness in 2004 trial of group of former Merrill Lynch and Enron executives who worked on illegal deal known as Nigerian barge transaction (M)

headline.main: A Witness at Odds With What Some Others Have Said

byline.original: By KURT EICHENWALD and ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO

docs.snippet: Even the most ardent followers of the federal government, the kind who spend hours watching C-Span, might have trouble remembering the names of any of the six previous holders of the office of comptroller general.    They were largely inconspicuou...
docs.lead_paragraph: Even the most ardent followers of the federal government, the kind who spend hours watching C-Span, might have trouble remembering the names of any of the six previous holders of the office of comptroller general. They were largely inconspicuous figures in a powerful but largely inconspicuous job, running the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress. But the office's seventh occupant, David M. Walker, has proved to be different.
docs.abstract: Profile of General Accounting Office Comptroller Gen David M Walker, who is suing Bush administration for disclosure of documents about how administration formulated its energy policy; Walker says he will file lawsuit to force Vice Pres Dick Cheney to turn over papers White House has refused to provide Congress; chart; photo (M)

headline.main: Man in the News; Pressing the President -- David Michael Walker

docs.snippet: The executive who handled investor relations at the Enron Corporation pleaded guilty on Wednesday to securities fraud. The executive, Mark E. Koenig, 49, pleaded guilty to one count of aiding and abetting securities fraud.     In a related civil a...
docs.lead_paragraph: The executive who handled investor relations at the Enron Corporation pleaded guilty on Wednesday to securities fraud. The executive, Mark E. Koenig, 49, pleaded guilty to one count of aiding and abetting securities fraud. In a related civil action brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Koenig agreed Wednesday to turn over to the government $1.49 million in forfeited assets and civil penalties and cooperate with government investigations.
docs.abstract: Mark E Koenig, who handled investor relations at Enron Corp, pleads guilty to securities fraud; Koenig, in related civil action brought by Securities and Exchange Commission, agrees to turn over to government $1.49 million in forfeited assets and civil penalties and cooperate with government probes (S)

headline.main: Former Executive of Enron Pleads Guilty
